diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Incidental finding on chest X-ray for pre-op clearance (knee surgery). Denies cough, SOB, chest pain.
diagnosis.relevantHistory: 40 pack-year smoking history (quit 5 yrs ago), Mild COPD.
diagnosis.baselineStatus: ECOG 1 (Restricted in physically strenuous activity but ambulatory)
diagnosis.pftSummary: FEV1 65% predicted, DLCO 60% predicted. Medically inoperable based on PFTs/comorbidities.

treatmentPlan.targetVolumeSummary: PTV encompassing RUL primary tumor with margin based on ITV from 4D-CT.
medications: Cough Syrup (e.g., Tessalon Perles) PRN radiation-induced cough
Consideration for short course of steroids if radiation pneumonitis develops

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Supine on wingboard with arms up, immobilized in BodyFix vacuum bag. Respiratory motion assessed using Varian RPM system. SAD setup.
ctSimulation.ctNotes: 4D-CT dataset acquired from lung apices through adrenal glands. Tumor motion assessed (~1.2 cm sup-inf). Data sent for SBRT planning using ITV approach.

dosimetry.isoCoords: e.g., L+5.0, P+8.0, S-2.0 (relative to reference)
dosimetry.norm: e.g., 95% of PTV covered by 100% of dose (54 Gy)
dosimetry.constraints: Spinal cord, heart, esophagus, contralateral lung, brachial plexus dose constraints met.
dosimetry.planNotes: SBRT VMAT plan completed using 4D-CT ITV approach.

fractions.setupNotes: Daily CBCT for IGRT. Matched to PTV.
fractions.sideEffects: Mild fatigue noted day after treatment.

fractions.setupNotes: Daily CBCT for IGRT. Setup consistent.
fractions.sideEffects: Mild fatigue persists. Minimal dry cough noted.

fractions.setupNotes: Daily CBCT for IGRT. Final fraction setup verified.
fractions.notes: Final fraction of SBRT course completed.

imagingAndReports.summary: 3 cm opacity RUL, recommend CT chest.

reportDetails.findings: Frontal and lateral views demonstrate a 3 cm opacity within the right upper lobe. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Heart size normal.
reportDetails.impression: Right upper lobe opacity, suspicious for malignancy. Recommend CT chest for further evaluation.

imagingAndReports.summary: 3.2 cm spiculated mass RUL, concerning for malignancy. No definite mediastinal adenopathy.

reportDetails.findings: A 3.2 cm spiculated mass is identified in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe. No definite mediastinal or hilar adenopathy exceeding 1 cm short axis. Small apical scarring noted bilaterally. Mild centrilobular emphysema.
reportDetails.impression: Right upper lobe mass highly suspicious for primary lung malignancy. No evidence of nodal involvement based on size criteria.

imagingAndReports.summary: Hypermetabolic RUL mass (SUV 8.9). No FDG-avid nodal or distant metastatic disease.

reportDetails.findings: Intense FDG uptake corresponding to the 3.2 cm right upper lobe mass (SUVmax 8.9). No FDG-avid lymph nodes identified in the mediastinum or hila. No suspicious FDG uptake elsewhere to suggest distant metastatic disease.
reportDetails.impression: Hypermetabolic right upper lobe mass consistent with primary malignancy. No evidence of regional nodal or distant metastatic disease (Stage I based on PET/CT).

reportDetails.specimen: CT-Guided Core Biopsy, Right Upper Lobe Lung Mass
reportDetails.diagnosis: NON-SMALL CELL LUNG CARCINOMA, FAVOR ADENOCARCINOMA.
reportDetails.microscopicDescription: Sections show core biopsy fragments containing nests and glandular structures formed by atypical epithelial cells with enlarged nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate amounts of cytoplasm infiltrating a desmoplastic stroma. Immunohistochemical stains are pending for definitive subtyping.
reportDetails.comment: Findings are diagnostic of non-small cell lung carcinoma. Features favor adenocarcinoma morphology. Awaiting molecular testing results if ordered separately.

imagingAndReports.summary: CT acquired with respiratory tracking (4D). Tumor motion assessed (~1.2 cm sup-inf).

reportDetails.setup: Patient positioned supine on wingboard with arms up, immobilized in BodyFix vacuum bag. Respiratory motion assessed using Varian RPM system.
reportDetails.scanParams: 4D CT dataset acquired from lung apices through adrenal glands using 2.5 mm slice thickness. Average intensity projection (AIP) and maximum intensity projection (MIP) reconstructions generated.
reportDetails.motionAssessment: Tumor motion measured approximately 1.2 cm in superior-inferior dimension, 0.4 cm anterior-posterior, 0.3 cm lateral.
reportDetails.notes: Patient tolerated procedure. Tattoos placed. Data sent for SBRT planning using ITV approach.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Susan Davis (Pulm)
progressNotes.summary: Pt referred for RUL mass on CT. PET/CT confirms FDG-avid lesion, N0M0. PFTs show FEV1 65%, DLCO 60%. Discussed w/ Thoracic Surgery - pt high risk for lobectomy due to PFTs. Refer to Rad Onc for definitive RT options (conventional vs SBRT).

progressNotes.author: Dr. Kevin Black (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt w/ Stage IB NSCLC, medically inoperable. Discussed definitive RT options. SBRT (54Gy/3fx) recommended given early stage and inoperability. Explained procedure, higher dose/fraction, potential side effects (fatigue, cough, chest wall pain, pneumonitis risk). Pt agrees. 4D Sim scheduled.

progressNotes.author: Physics/Dosimetry
progressNotes.summary: SBRT VMAT plan completed using 4D-CT ITV approach. Dose constraints met for spinal cord, heart, esophagus, contralateral lung, brachial plexus. Plan approved by Dr. Black.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Kevin Black (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt completed Fx 1 SBRT yesterday. Reports mild fatigue today. No significant cough, pain or SOB. Tolerating well. Continue SBRT as planned next treatment day.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Kevin Black (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Completed Fx 2 SBRT yesterday. Mild fatigue persists. Minimal dry cough. No chest wall pain. Tolerating well. Final fraction scheduled.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: Definitive treatment with curative intent using SBRT.
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: Fatigue (common), cough, shortness of breath, chest wall soreness/pain (can occur weeks/months later), skin irritation (less common with SBRT), radiation pneumonitis (inflammation of lung, risk discussed), potential for rib fracture (rare, long term).
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Importance of attending all scheduled treatments, reporting symptoms like worsening cough, shortness of breath, fever, or significant pain promptly.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend appointments, report symptoms, maintain usual activity as tolerated.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Use PRN cough syrup as needed. Follow up instructions regarding any potential steroid use if pneumonitis develops.
